metadata.h1: Can we teach a computer quantum mechanics? (Part I)

all_paragraphs: Authors: Kaiah Steven, Matthew Rose, Tyler Jones and Xavier Poncini (Quantum Machine Learning Research Team, Max Kelsen)

It has been hailed as the next general technology to shake the world, much in the same way the advent of the Turing machine launched the age of information. Quantum computers have been promised to bring with them untold computational power. Despite our best efforts however, we’ve yet to see a physically realised quantum computer outperform it’s classical counterpart. The road to quantum supremacy is a long one; fortunately this is not our first computational revolution. With the aid of resources and experience from the world of classical computing we can chart the path of least resistance to the development of this revolutionary technology.

Part I of this blog will delve into the use of quantum mechanics to facilitate efficient computation. Then, as we seek to tackle the paradox of simultaneous control and isolation of quantum bits, Part II of this blog discusses how we intend to hand the problem over to machines through reinforcement learning.

The story begins with our most fundamental theory of reality, quantum mechanics. Notoriously counter-intuitive, such a description predicts two phenomena which when exploited, form the basis of quantum computation.The first effect, superposition, can be thought of as when one physical system can simultaneously exist in multiple different states. This superposition persists until the quantum state is perturbed (e.g. measurement) resulting in the ‘collapse’ into a single classical state. Entering the quantum regime, our standard computation unit can be upgraded from a simple bit possessing a 0 or 1 state, to a qubit which can possess any possible combination of 0 and 1 states.

The second effect is entanglement. Faithful to its name, such a process entwines two or more objects together, ensuring they share a correlated fate. Suppose we entangle two qubits, the state of each qubit is undefined. Mathematically, an independent description of each qubit is impossible, one is only able to describe the system as a whole. Consequently the collapse and measurement of one qubit in our pair instantaneously influences the state of the other.

How are the phenomena of superposition and entanglement useful in efficient computations? Firstly, they allow us to produce a quantum mechanical analogue of a universal Turing machine. This is achieved by defining a set of operations, the finite sequence of which can perform any possible computation. Secondly, perhaps the most exciting prospect, is the leveraging of superposition to compute a large number of scenarios in parallel. Such computation capabilities lend themselves to the efficient solution of multi-variable optimisation problems — naturally arising throughout all industry sectors (see examples in finance and big data).

We are currently at the beginning of our journey to quantum supremacy — having access to what has been termed noisy intermediate-scale quantum computers (NISQ). One of the biggest impediments of these devices is decoherence, which sets an expiration date on every qubit. The information contained in quantum systems eventually “leaks” out into the environment until the system you’re working with loses its quantumness, becoming effectively unusable.

This results in a set window of time to perform quantum computations (see quantum error correction for getting around this problem permanently). Hence, time becomes a resource which must be spent efficiently to get the most out of quantum computing. Accordingly, research has focused on finding the quickest way to perform quantum algorithms. Finding this optimal solution is by no means an easy problem, and remains an open research question today.

A particular formulation of quantum computation is provided by the circuit model. Here, unitary operations performed on qubits are represented with gates. Universal quantum computation does not uniquely define a set of gates — as such there exist many sets achieving this end. For our purposes we will focus on the gate set which consists of X, Z, H, CNOT. Such a gate set is not universal (under standard conditions), however it will allow us to access both superposition and entanglement states. Before we create our first quantum circuit we will introduce two ideas, each essential in developing an intuition for the types of operations to be performed by these machines.

It is not necessarily clear how one would determine U, generating an arbitrary final state S and whether this particular U is efficient. A natural question of automation arises: Is it possible to construct a model that takes an input output state pair and generates an efficient circuit facilitating this transition?

Our subsequent research endeavoured to answer this question. Given the recent success of machine learning — revolutionising the fields of computer vision, robotics and many others — we sought to survey this space in order to examine possible paradigms and architectures that may have the ability to learn the structure of the computational landscape.

It was soon apparent that such a problem could be cast similar to a video game. We have some initial state, a finite set of operations and a final state, we just don’t know the best way to get there. With reinforcement learning claiming victories against domain experts in chess and Go it seemed natural to challenge physicists to find the path of least resistance in the generation of efficient quantum circuits.
See Part II for our implementation.
